attributes.comment:
I am writing to ask that the proposed fee increase for a Certificate of Citizenship
(C.O.C.) be defeated. Further, I ask that the currents fees associated with a
Certificate of Citizenship be waived for international adoptees entering this country
with any type of visa.

International adoption is expensive. I have two small children adopted from South
Korea and cannot afford to get them both a Certificate of Citizenship because the
fees are so high. If my children were adopted from China and entered the United
States on an R-3 visa, the Certificate of Citizenship would be sent to them for no
additional fee. But, because my children entered this country with an R-4 visa, I
must pay outrageous fees in order to obtain C.O.C.'s for them.

I know of many hardworking adoptive parents who have made huge sacrifices in an
effort to raise the money needed for an international adoption. To make these
parents pay $200-$500 for a certificate from the government that "proves" they are
U.S. Citizens when the federal Child Citizenship Act of 2004 grants our children
citizenship is aggregious. Many adoptees need this certificate to prove their
citizenship. The Social Security Administration requires a US passport or a
C.O.C. to prove U.S. citizenship. Both of my children are listed as "resident
aliens" even though I have finalized their adoptions in probate court in the United
States. I have to pay additional money for documents that I do not need for any
other reason in order to have my children's citizenship status changed at the
SSA.

Please consider waiving all fees associated with a Certificate of Citizenship for
ALL internationally adopted children in this country.

SIncerely,
Michele Breen
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Michele Breen
